docs.lead_paragraph: For three generations, an enormous Cadillac factory stretched across eight blocks on the southwest side of the Motor City, providing a path to the middle class for tens of thousands of workers. It closed a decade ago, becoming a vast, derelict monument to the decay of a great manufacturing center. The surrounding neighborhood deteriorated almost as fast as the weeds grew up around the factory. The only high-paying job nearby was drug dealing. But for the last two years, the inner city where the factory is situated -- an endless sprawl of blocks so bleak that rundown houses can sell for less than used cars -- has been a magnet for business.

headline.main: U.S. Program Helps Return Industry to Depressed Area
headline.kicker: A Revival In the Motor City

docs.abstract: Article on economic revival of Detroit, Mich; says since 1994, when Federal Government designated an 18.350-square-mile stretch of the city as one of six urban empowerment zones in the nation, 29 companies have announced plans to spend $2.17 billion opening, expanding or relocating their operations in Detroit zone; says this week, Chrysler Corp pledged to increase its spending in the area, where it builds Jeep Grand Cherokees, to $1.65 billion from $750 million; also says that when Vice Pres Al Gore and redevelopment specialists come to Detroit for conference next week, they are expected to give empowerment zone much of credit for beginning to bring back Detroit; map; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Three of the seven Republican Senators who were identified on Tuesday as co-sponsors of bills to provide children's health insurance by raising the cigarette tax said today that they supported the insurance but not the tax. So did the Senate minority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota. None offered a specific alternative plan for raising the money.

headline.main: 3 Senators Set To Oppose Tax For Health Bill

docs.abstract: Three of seven Republican Senators, identified as co-sponsors of bills to provide children's health insurance by raising cigarette tax, say they support insurance but not tax; identified as Sens Orrin Hatch, Ted Stevens and Ben Nighthorse Campbell (S)
docs.snippet: Three of the seven Republican Senators who were identified on Tuesday as co-sponsors of bills to provide children's health insurance by raising the cigarette tax said today that they supported the insurance but not the tax. So did the Senate minority...

docs.lead_paragraph: Eight Senate Republicans, including three committee chairmen, lined up today behind legislation that would raise cigarette taxes to pay for health insurance for children now uninsured, giving a striking boost to the bill's prospects. Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican who heads the Senate Judiciary Committee, recruited seven others from his party to co-sponsor the bill, which he introduced today with Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.

headline.main: 8 G.O.P. SENATORS BACK BILL TO AID UNINSURED YOUTHS

docs.abstract: Eight Senate Republicans support legislation that would raise cigarette taxes to pay for health insurance for uninsured children; Sen Orrin G Hatch, who heads Senate Judiciary Committee, recruits seven others from his party to co-sponsor bill, which he introduces with Sen Edward M Kennedy on April 8; measure would increase Federal cigarette tax to 67 cents a pack, from current 24 cents, yielding $20 billion a year in grants to states so they could provide insurance for children whose low-income working parents do not qualify for Medicaid; Senate majority leader Trent Lott opposes measure; other Republican co-sponsors of bill are Sens Ted Stevens, James M Jeffords, Robert F Bennett, Ben Nighthorse Campbell, Susan Collins, Olympia J Snowe and Gordon H Smith: Hatch and Kennedy photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Street Battles in Hebron Follow Palestinian's Death A Jewish settler shot and killed an Arab in Hebron, igniting fierce street battles between rock-throwing youths and Israeli soldiers in which two more Palestinians were killed and about 100 were wounded. Palestinian policemen, working with the Israelis, restored calm only after hours of fighting. A12

docs.lead_paragraph: When officials of Metropolitan Life Insurance Company were trying to figure out what to do with their 1930's building on Madison Avenue between 24th and 25th Streets, they knew they had one big advantage: huge floors in the block-square building. After landing the investment banking company CS First Boston as the anchor tenant, with 1.6 million of the 2.2 million square feet of space available, Met Life's officials made the building's layout part of their strategy.
docs.abstract: Metropolitan Life Insurance Company office building on Madison Avenue between 24th and 25th Streets has attracted CS First Boston as its primary tenant; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In her latest and perhaps boldest break from her fellow Republicans, including Gov. George E. Pataki, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross today backed Democratic state senators who tried to force a vote on a bill she wrote that would require insurers to cover some experimental medical treatments. The Republican-controlled Senate voted 34 to 25, along strict party lines, against a motion to take up the bill, which was sponsored by Senator Catherine M. Abate, a Manhattan Democrat.

headline.main: Lieutenant Governor Breaks With Party on Insurance

docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration offered today to make additional cuts of $18 billion in projected Medicare spending over the next five years to help reach agreement on eliminating the Federal deficit, people involved in the budget negotiations said today. In saying that it was willing to compromise further on Medicare, the issue that has most divided the Administration and Congressional Republicans through two years of budget wars, the White House was clearly seeking to appear flexible as the two sides began their first serious negotiations since their impasse in late 1995 led to a Government shutdown.

headline.main: PRESIDENT OFFERS $18 BILLION MORE IN MEDICARE CUTS

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration offers to make additional cuts of $18 billion in projected Medicare spending over next five years to help reach agreement on eliminating Federal deficit; Administration, in saying that it is willing to compromise further on Medicare, is seeking to appear flexible as two sides begin their first serious negotiations since their impasse in late 1995 led to Government shutdown; Administration had previously proposed plan that it said would cut growth of Government health care spending for elderly by $100 billion over five years, while most recent Republican offer was $158 billion over six years; Republicans say they welcome Administration's proposal but want to study it further (M)
docs.snippet: The Clinton Administration offered today to make additional cuts of $18 billion in projected Medicare spending over the next five years to help reach agreement on eliminating the Federal deficit, people involved in the budget negotiations said today....

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Columbia Hospital Corporation is buying hundreds of hospitals across the country, US Healthcare and Aetna merge to form a multibillion-dollar health insurance monolith, but when Staples and Office Depot try to merge, the Federal Trade Commission rushes in to stop it (front page, April 5). After all, you don't want anyone messing with something as important as office supplies! Am I missing something? DAVID E. MANDELBAUM, M.D. New Brunswick, N.J., April 7, 1997
docs.abstract: Dr David E Mandelbaum letter questions why Federal Government allowed US Healthcare and Aetna to merge but challenged proposed merger of Office Depot and Staples office supply companies

docs.lead_paragraph: Steven Millhauser is an English professor at Skidmore College and a novelist little noticed outside publishing circles. But he moved quickly onto center stage yesterday when his fourth novel, ''Martin Dressler: The Tale of an American Dreamer,'' won the 1997 Pulitzer Prize for fiction. Michael G. Gartner stood at the pinnacle of the media business as president of NBC News until he resigned in 1993 and became full-time editor of The Daily Tribune of Ames, Iowa, circulation 10,000. His editorials -- about such local topics as beer drinking in Bandshell Park and the proper location for the new Lowe's Home Improvement Center -- earned a Pulitzer for editorial writing.

headline.main: 20 Pulitzer Prizes Are Announced With a Theme of Personal Impact on Lives

docs.abstract: Twenty Pulitzer Prizes are awarded; winners include: Richard Kluger (General Nonfiction) for book Ashes to Ashes, Wynton Marsalis (Music) for jazz oratorio, Lisel Mueller (Poetry) for Alive Together: New and Selected Poems, Jack N Rakove (History) for Original Meanings: Politics and Ideas in the Making of the Constitution, Walt Handelsman of Times-Picayune of New Orleans (Editorial Cartooning), Steven Millhauser (Fiction) for book Martin Dressler: The Tale of an American Dreamer, Frank McCourt (Biography) for Angela's Ashes, Byron Acohido of Seattle Times (Best Reporting), Alexander Zemlianichenko of Associated Press (Feature Photogtaphy), Annie Wells of Press-Democrat of Santa Rosa (Spot News Photography, Times-Picayune of New Orleans (Public Service), Newsday (Spot News Reporting), Michael G Gartner of Daily Tribune of Ames, Iowa, (Editorial Writing), John F Burns of New York Times (International Reporting), Wall Street Journal (National Reporting), Michael Vitez, April Saul and Ron Cortes of Philadelphia Inquirer (Explanatory Journalism), Eric Nalder, Deborah Nelson and Alex Tizon of Seattle Times (Investigative Reporting), Lisa Pollack of Baltimore Sun (Feature Writing), Eileen McNamara of Boston Globe (Commentary) and Tim Page of Washington Post (Criticism); there is no prize awarded for drama (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Union construction workers demonstrated yesterday outside a downtown office building that they said a developer was transforming into apartments using state tax incentives but with nonunion labor. About 4,000 men and women, many on their lunch break from nearby work sites, jammed three blocks outside 80 John Street, waving the pennants of dozens of locals, shouting slogans and holding signs like a handwritten one that asked, ''Can I have a fat tax break when I'm unemployed?''
docs.abstract: Union construction workers demonstrate outside downtown office building that they say developer WSA Equities is transforming into apartments using state tax incentives but with nonunion labor; photo (S)
